definitions.definition: used to show what is right, appropriate, etc., especially when criticizing somebody’s actions

examples.text: You shouldn't drink and drive.
He should have been more careful.
A present for me? You **shouldn't have**! *(= used to thank somebody politely)*

definitions.definition: used for giving or asking for advice

examples.text: You should stop worrying about it.
Should I call him and apologize?
**I should** wait a little longer, **if I were you**.
‘She doesn't think she'll get a job.’ ‘She should worry, with all her qualifications *(= she does not need to worry)*.’

definitions.definition: used to say that you expect something is true or will happen

examples.text: We should arrive before dark.
I should have finished the book by Friday.
The roads should be less crowded today.

definitions.definition: used to say that something that was expected has not happened

examples.text: It should be snowing now, according to the weather forecast.
The bus should have arrived ten minutes ago.

definitions.definition: used as the past form of shall when reporting what somebody has said

examples.text: He asked me what time he should come. *(= His words were: ‘What time shall I come?’)*
I said (that) I should be glad to help.

definitions.definition: used after that when something is suggested or arranged

examples.text: She recommended that I should take some time off.
In order that training should be effective it must be planned systematically.

definitions.definition: used with I and we to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.text: I should imagine it will take about three hours.
‘Is this enough food for everyone?’ ‘**I should think so**.’
‘Will it matter?’ ‘**I shouldn't think so**.’
‘I know it's expensive but it will last for years.’ ‘**I should hope so too!**’
‘Nobody will oppose it.’ ‘**I should think not!**’

definitions.definition: used to refuse something or to show that you are annoyed at a request; used to express surprise about an event or a situation
definitions.sensetop: why, how, who, what should somebody/something do

examples.text: Why should I help him? He's never done anything for me.
How should I know where you've left your bag?
I got on the bus and who should be sitting in front of me but Tony!

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that something would surprise them or make them laugh if they saw or experienced it

examples.text: You should have seen her face when she found out!

definitions.definition: used after that after many adjectives that describe feelings

examples.text: I'm anxious that we should allow plenty of time.
I find it astonishing that he should be so rude to you.

definitions.definition: used with I and we in polite requests

examples.text: I should like to call my lawyer.
We should be grateful for your help.

definitions.definition: used after I or we instead of would for describing what you would do if something else happened first

examples.text: If I were asked to work on Sundays, I should resign.

definitions.definition: used to refer to a possible event or situation

examples.text: If you should change your mind, do let me know.
In case you should need any help, here's my number.
Should anyone call *(= if anyone calls)*, please tell them I'm busy.

wordOrigin: Old English sceolde: past of shall.
